column4: Commercial tobacco farming and manufacturing no longer occurs in Australia. However, the Commonwealth and state and territory governments have environmental and occupational health and safety legislation, regulation and policies in place to protect the environment and the health of persons in relation to the environment. Tobacco manufacturers are subject to these requirements if they return their operations to Australia.
column5: Commercial tobacco farming no longer occurs in Australia. Three tobacco manufacturing companies operate in Australia. The Commonwealth and state and territory governments have environmental and occupational health and safety legislation. regulation and policies in place to protect the environment and the health of persons in relation to the environment. Tobacco manufacturers are subject to these requirements.

column4:
On 2013 MDA contracted extension services to assist 11.200 tobacco producers in the Southern States of Rio Grande do Sul, Santa Catarina and Paraná, where is concentrated 98% of tobacco for cigarrettes produced in Brazil.
These are 3 years contracts and include subjects related to “diversification of production and income, commercialization, value adding, farmer organization, and others related to the FCTC, such as, the health of tobacco producers, protection and conservation of natural resources, and awareness raising about the objectives of the FCTC. 
Apart from the contracts on diversification, MDA also contracted extension services on municipalities that produce tobacco, to assist another 33.400 families on other topics such as, agroecology, dairy activities, coffee production, and sustainability.
Furthermore, it has a specific item on its budget that supports training of farmers and extension agents, implementation of demonstration units on economic viable alternatives to tobacco, and research concerning diversification.

column5:
From November 17 2011 in Bulgaria can offer only „cigarettes with reduced ignition propensity” or so-called „RIP cigarettes” (Reduced Ignition Propensity). All cigarettes at the market will have to conform the standard EN 16156:2010 on fire „Cigarettes. Evaluation of the ignition propensity. Safety requirement. „The standard was developed under a mandate from the European Commission and the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) and supports essential requirements for the general safety of products in accordance with Directive 2001/95/EC.
Compliance with the standard is mandatory for manufacturers and for retailers of tobacco products - cigarettes and supplies for RYO cigarettes. The conformity assessment of cigarettes will be evidenced by a document certifying the results of the laboratory tests of the burning ability of cigarette paper.
In Bulgaria requirements for fire safety about tobacco products are provided in Standard EN 16156:2010 „Cigarettes. Evaluation of the ignition propensity. Safety” in connection with BDS EN ISO 12863:2010 ”Standard method for assessing the ignition propensity of cigarettes” under the provisions of the Directive on general product safety 2001/95/EC of the European Parliament and the Council therefore that they are made of cigarette paper with a reduced ability of ignition..

Health Canadas Pest Management Regulatory Agency (PMRA) regulates pesticides for all agricultural crops, including tobacco. In doing so, it takes health and the environment into consideration.  

While the Tobacco Act does not provide environmental measures with respect to manufacturing, Canada has extensive national and sub-national legislation and regulations that provide for the protection of the environment, labour standards, and measures that protect the health of persons in relation to the environment.

Rural Development programmes 2014-2020 may grant an aid (per hectare) to compensate the loss of revenue for farmers (lower yield or higher costs) that implement more "environment friendly" practices. These practices cover different aspects of cultivation, such as: set-aside areas, areas not cultivated along rivers, lake or wood; less use of fertilizers and/or pesticides; better irrigation…Aid may also be granted for training and exchange of experiences, as well as for reforestation. These measures may indirectly protect health of the farmers and (seasonal) workers.

Pakistan Tobacco Board keeps working with the different stakeholders to run programs that include training of farmers regarding safe use of pesticides, integrated pest management, and use of specially formulated fertilizer. 

The following laws are applicable to tobacco manufacturing process in Pakistan:
a.	Pakistan Environmental Protection Act 1997 and National Environmental Quality Standards.
b.	Section 14 of Factorys Act 1934, Factories Rules 1978, Electricity Rules, 1937, and Boiler and Pressure Vessels Ordinance 2002.
column5:

2.	Tobacco Control Cell is planning to collaborate with Pakistan Tobacco Board to raise the issue of protection of the health of tobacco cultivators.
3.	The following laws are applicable to tobacco manufacturing process in Pakistan:
a.	Pakistan Environmental Protection Act 1997 and National Environmental Quality Standards.
b.	Section 14 of Factory''s Act 1934 Factories Rules 1978 Electricity Rules 1937 and Boiler and Pressure Vessels Ordinance 2002.

En España, se pueden distinguir medidas de protección del medio ambiente en los siguientes ámbitos:
*	Dentro del primer pilar de la política agraria comunitaria (PAC): 
En el marco de los pagos directos, la última reforma de la PAC da una mayor importancia a la sostenibilidad medioambiental de la agricultura dentro del primer pilar de la PAC, en la UE. 
Así, esta nueva PAC dentro de los pagos directos, ha introducido un nuevo pago denominado “Pago para prácticas agrícolas beneficiosas para el clima y el medio ambiente” (conocida comúnmente como “greening” o “pago verde”). Este pago es obligatorio para los agricultores y cuenta con una dotación presupuestaria de un 30% del sobre nacional de cada Estado miembro, de la UE, dentro de los pagos directos. Se concede un pago anual por cada hectárea admisible, siempre que se respeten determinadas prácticas medioambientales, dependiendo de la estructura de la explotación. Así, los agricultores con derecho a un pago en virtud del “régimen de pago básico” deben respetar dichas prácticas en todas las hectáreas de su explotación.
Se consideran prácticas beneficiosas para el clima y el medio ambiente: la diversificación de cultivos, el mantenimiento de los pastos permanentes existentes y contar con superficies de interés ecológico en la explotación (barbecho, superficies dedicadas a cultivos fijadores de nitrógeno, superficies forestadas y superficies dedicadas a agrosilvicultura). Estas prácticas de “greening” buscan mejorara el comportamiento ambiental y de cara al cambio climático de las explotaciones.
Al tratarse el tabaco de un cultivo en tierra arable, le afecta el cumplimiento de la diversificación de cultivos y de las superficies de interés ecológico, que el agricultor deberá respectar en función de la estructura de su explotación. En concreto, estas dos prácticas van dirigidas directamente a la mejora del suelo y a la biodiversidad, con efectos también en lo que tiene que ver con la mitigación del cambio climático.
*	Dentro del segundo pilar de la PAC: 
En Extremadura (principal región productora de tabaco en España, con el 95,38% de la producción total), en el marco de su PDR, existe una medida agroambiental que favorece la producción integrada de tabaco, haciendo este cultivo más sostenible desde el punto de vista medioambiental.
Por otro lado, se hace control de la implantación de las regulaciones sobre salud laboral y sobre protección al medio ambiente en el entorno laboral.
